Name: Technical Controls
Description: Implemented using technology or systems. Examples: firewalls, antivirus, intrusion detection, access controls.

Name: Managerial Controls
Description: Administrative measures that define security design and policy. Examples: security policies, risk assessments, standard operating procedures.

Name: Operational Controls
Description: Implemented and executed by people. Examples: security awareness training, incident response procedures, background checks.

Name: Physical Controls
Description: Restrict physical access to systems and facilities. Examples: fences, locks, badge readers, guard stations.

Name: Control Types
Description: Preventive, Deterrent, Detective, Corrective, Compensating, Directive

Name: Preventive Control
Description: Prevents security incidents by stopping unwanted or unauthorized activity before it occurs. Examples include firewalls, locks, and access control lists.

Name: Deterrent Control
Description: Discourages potential attackers or policy violations through visible warnings or consequences. Examples include security signs, guards, and surveillance cameras.

Name: Detective Control
Description: Identifies and alerts when a security incident occurs or has occurred. Examples include intrusion detection systems (IDS), CCTV monitoring, and log reviews.

Name: Corrective Control
Description: Responds to and fixes issues after they have been detected. Examples include restoring backups, patching vulnerabilities, and reimaging compromised systems.

Name: Compensating Control
Description: Provides alternative protection when the primary control cannot be implemented. Examples include manual review processes or temporary technical safeguards.

Name: Directive Control
Description: Guides or enforces expected behavior within the organization. Examples include security policies, acceptable use policies, and posted procedures.

Name: CIA Triad
Description: Confidentiality – prevent unauthorized access (encryption, access control). Integrity – ensure accuracy (hashing, checksums). Availability – ensure access (redundancy, backups).

Name: Non-Repudiation and Integrity Proofs
Description: Non-repudiation prevents denial of actions (digital signatures, logs). Proof of Integrity verifies data unchanged (hashing). Proof of Origin confirms sender identity (authentication, signatures).

Name: AAA Framework
Description: Identification – claim identity (username). Authentication – verify identity (password, MFA). Authorization – define access. Accounting – logs user actions.

Name: Authentication Flow
Description: User enters credentials. Firewall or VPN forwards to AAA server. Server validates credentials. Access granted if approved.

Name: Certificate-Based Authentication
Description: Uses digital certificates issued by a Certificate Authority (CA). Verifies identity using public-key cryptography. Used in VPNs, Wi-Fi, secure email.

Name: Authorization Models
Description: Define how access is granted. RBAC (Role-Based), ABAC (Attribute-Based), MAC/DAC. Abstraction groups permissions to simplify management.

Name: Security Assessments
Description: Gap Analysis – compare current vs desired state. Baseline – define standard configuration. Reporting – identify weaknesses and improvements.

Name: Zero Trust Architecture
Description: Principle: never trust, always verify. Includes data/control planes, adaptive identity, policy enforcement points, and threat scope reduction.

Name: Physical Security Controls
Description: Barricades, fences, bollards, CCTV, guards, badges, and access vestibules restrict or monitor access.

Name: Deception and Detection Tools
Description: Honeypots, honeynets, honeyfiles, and honeytokens attract attackers or detect misuse.

Name: Change Management
Description: Structured process for managing IT changes. Includes ownership, stakeholders, impact analysis, sandbox testing, backout plan, and documentation.

Name: Software and System Controls
Description: Allow list – approved applications only. Deny list – block malicious software. Maintain redundancy and isolate legacy systems.

Name: Public Key Infrastructure (PKI)
Description: Framework for managing certificates and encryption keys. Supports symmetric/asymmetric encryption and key escrow.

Name: Encryption Practices
Description: Data at rest – BitLocker, FileVault. Data in transit – TLS, VPN. Data in use – secure memory. Use AES/RSA/ECC with strong key management.

Name: Cryptographic Hardware
Description: TPM, HSM, KMS, and Secure Enclave manage encryption keys securely and isolate sensitive operations.

Name: Data Obfuscation and Privacy
Description: Obfuscation hides intent. Steganography hides data in media. Tokenization replaces sensitive data. Data masking hides parts of data.

Name: Hashing and Digital Signatures
Description: Hashing verifies integrity. SHA-256 is secure. MD5/SHA-1 are obsolete. Digital signatures verify authenticity and non-repudiation.

Name: Blockchain
Description: Immutable distributed ledger linking transactions with hashes. Used for secure tracking and verification.

Name: Digital Certificates and Trust
Description: X.509 certificates bind keys to identities. Managed by Certificate Authorities (CAs). Includes CSRs, SANs, and wildcard certificates.

Name: Certificate Revocation
Description: CRL lists revoked certs. OCSP checks validity in real time. OCSP stapling improves performance.
